john_doe.title: Itchy Skin with Redness
john_doe.shortSummary: Moderate itchy skin and redness on torso, possibly an allergic reaction to shellfish consumption, further evaluation and management by a specialist are necessary.

john_doe.title: Cough
john_doe.shortSummary: Moderate dry cough for 4 days, likely due to upper respiratory tract infection or environmental irritant, further testing recommended.

john_doe.title: Fever and Body Aches
john_doe.shortSummary: Mild fever and body aches likely due to viral infection, rest and monitor symptoms.

john_doe.title: Mild Stomach Pain
john_doe.shortSummary: Mild stomach pain after eating spicy food, likely gastritis, avoid spicy food and consider antacids if needed.

john_doe.title: Headache and Fatigue
john_doe.shortSummary: Experiencing mild headache and fatigue, likely due to tension and stress. Recommended to rest, hydrate, and manage stress.

john_doe.title: Cough
john_doe.shortSummary: A 4-day history of cough, possibly related to upper respiratory tract infection or allergic reaction, further testing and evaluation are necessary.

john_doe.title: Stomach Ache
john_doe.shortSummary: The stomach ache may be related to gastrointestinal issues or a medication side effect, and further evaluation is necessary to determine the underlying cause and develop an appropriate treatment plan.

john_doe.title: Cold Symptoms
john_doe.shortSummary: You have symptoms of a common cold, possibly related to a viral upper respiratory tract infection, with indications of stress or anxiety. Further tests and consultation with a healthcare professional are recommended.

john_doe.title: Stomach Ache
john_doe.shortSummary: The patient presents with a 2-day history of stomach ache, possibly related to gastrointestinal issues, migraine, or other causes, requiring further evaluation.

john_doe.title: Forearm Fracture
john_doe.shortSummary: Severe forearm fracture from an accident, requiring further evaluation and treatment by an orthopedic surgeon to promote healing and proper function.

john_doe.title: Forearm Fracture
john_doe.shortSummary: You have a fracture of both radius and ulna bones in your forearm, which requires immediate medical attention to avoid further complications. You may need additional tests and orthopedic surgery.
